hu.elte.txtuml.api

Class StateMachine

  • java.lang.Object
    • hu.elte.txtuml.api.StateMachine
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ModelElement
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Region

    public abstract class StateMachine
extends java.lang.Object
implements ModelElement
    Base class for state machines in the model.

    Represents: state machine

    Usage:

    StateMachine might not be used directly. However, ModelClass itself extends StateMachine and therefore every model class may have an implicit state machine by defining vertices and transitions as its inner classes.

    A txtUML state machine consists of inner classes of a subclass of StateMachine, all of which inner classes extend either Vertex or Transition. A single initial pseudostate (a subclass of Initial) and a single unlabeled transition (one that has no Trigger annotation defined) from that initial pseudostate is required, without it, the state machine is ill-formed and does not run. Therefore, a ModelClass might either have a complete state machine by applying to these rules or no state machine at all (no inner classes extending Vertex or Transition).

    Apart from the obligatory initial pseudostate and initial transition, a txtUML state machine may contain any number of states (subclasses of StateMachine.State), choice pseudostates (subclasses of StateMachine.Choice), composite states (subclasses of StateMachine.CompositeState) to implement hierarchical state machines, and transitions (subclasses of StateMachine.Transition). For details about their use, see the documentation of the regarding classes. For examples, see below.

    Java restrictions:

    • Instantiate: disallowed
    • Define subtype: disallowed, extend ModelClass

    Examples:

    The minimal state machine consists of an initial pseudostate, a state and a transition between the two. 

     
 class SampleClass extends ModelClass {
 
        class Init extends Initial {}
 
        class S1 extends State {}
 
         @From(Init.class) @To(S1.class)
        class Initialize extends Transition {}
 }
    Guards and effects might be applied to transitions. For the example, let us assume that the signal SampleSignal has a field (a signal parameter) sampleParam of type ModelInt. 
     
 class SampleClass2 extends ModelClass {
 
        //...
 
         @From(SourceState.class) @To(TargetState.class) @Trigger(SampleSignal.class)
        class SampleTransition extends Transition {
                 @Override
                public void effect() {
                        Action.log("Transition effect");
                }
 
                 @Override
                public ModelBool guard() {
                        SampleSignal sg = getSignal(SampleSignal.class); 
                        return sg.sampleParam.isEqual(ModelInt.ZERO);
                }
        }
 
        //...
 
 }
    A state having its entry and exit actions defined. 
     
 class SampleClass3 extends ModelClass {
 
        //...
 
        class SampleState extends State {
                 @Override
                public void entry() {
                        Action.log("Entry action");
                }
 
                 @Override
                public void exit() {
                        Action.log("Exit action");
                }
        }
 
        //...
 
 }
    A composite state with a choice pseudostate inside. When the state machine enters the composite state, it changes to the choice pseudostate. If the attribute i has a value of zero, the FromChoice1 transition will be chosen to S1, otherwise the FromChoice2 transition to S2. 
     
 class SampleClass4 extends ModelClass {
 
        //...
 
        ModelInt i = //...
 
        class SampleCompositeState extends CompositeState {
                class Init extends Initial {}
                class SampleChoice extends Choice {}
                class S1 extends State {}
                class S2 extends State {}
 
                 @From(Init.class) @To(SampleChoice.class)
                class Initialize extends Transition {}
 
                 @From(SampleChoice.class) @To(S1.class)
                class FromChoice1 extends Transition {
                         @Override
                        public ModelBool guard() {
                                return i.isEqual(ModelInt.ZERO);
                        }
                }
 
                 @From(SampleChoice.class) @To(S2.class)
                class FromChoice2 extends Transition {
                         @Override
                        public ModelBool guard() {
                                return ModelBool.ELSE;
                        }
                }
 
                //...
 
        }
 
        //...
 
 }
    See the documentation of Model for an overview on modeling in txtUML.
    Author:
    Gabor Ferenc Kovacs
    See Also:
    StateMachine.Vertex, StateMachine.Pseudostate, StateMachine.Initial, StateMachine.Choice, StateMachine.State, StateMachine.CompositeState
